I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The water policy1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), approved in January 2001, 
promotes national water sector reforms, integrated water resources management (IWRM), and 
improved water services for the poor. In addition, the policy commits ADB to regional and 
subregional cooperation by helping to assess the water sector and exchange data, enhancing 
awareness and understanding of water sector issues and each country’s needs, and supporting 
water partnerships in ADB’s developing member countries.  
 
2.  To  stimulate  the  adoption  of  a  more  strategic  and  sustainable  approach  to  water 
resources, the 2002 World Summit on Sustainable Development called for all countries to 
develop IWRM and water efficiency plans by the end of 2005. During the summit, a number of 
governments and funding institutions committed to various financial assistance initiatives to 
encourage  the  institutionalization  of  key  changes  that  would  promote  more  strategic  and 
coordinated decision-making processes in relation to the development, management, and use 
of water resources to advance sustainability goals and meet development challenges. These 
commitments included that of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands to make an initial 
contribution to ADB, through a separate technical assistance (TA) arrangement, for the purpose 
of supporting the process of developing IWRM plans in Bangladesh, Indonesia, Pakistan, and 
Viet Nam. 
 
3.  For this purpose, the governments of the participating countries (the governments) have 
requested ADB to prepare a TA that will promote effective and efficient preparation of IWRM 
plans and programs in their respective countries. The TA was prepared in consultation with 
various stakeholders. ADB missions and follow-up consultations were conducted from October 
2004 to February 2006 to formulate the TA and reach an understanding with the governments 
on  the  goal,  purpose,  activities  and  inputs,  outcomes  and  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, costs and financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA.2 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
  
II.  ISSUES 
 
4. Many countries in the Asia and Pacific region are experiencing water-related problems 
that are proving intractable to conventional, single-sector approaches. Problems of drought, 
flooding, groundwater overdraft,3 waterborne diseases, land and water degradation, ongoing 
damage  to  ecosystems,  and  escalating  conflicts  over  water  have  proven  hard  to  address 
because solutions often fall outside the normal purview of the agencies tasked with addressing 
such problems and require cooperation by agencies in multiple sectors. 
 
5.  The geographical location of Bangladesh, for example, in an alluvial, deltaic floodplain 
created by the confluence of three major rivers (the Ganges, the Brahmaputra, and the Meghna) 
causes massive challenges in terms of flooding during the monsoon season; water scarcity 
during the dry season; erosion; saline intrusion and environmental degradation, particularly in 
the southwest; cyclones; and heavy arsenic contamination of groundwater. Water management 
is further complicated by the country’s dense population and expanding economic activities, with 
severe implications for its rich and vulnerable ecosystems. Bangladesh has recently set up an 
effective policy, planning, and institutional framework for comprehensive management of its

water resources that includes the 1999 national water policy and the 2004 national watershed 
management  plan  (NWMP).  However,  NMWP  objectives  are  yet  to  be  fully  achieved  as 
implementation takes a slow pace.  
 
6.  In Indonesia, continued deforestation causes landslides, river sedimentation, increased 
flooding, and losses of livelihoods and lives. Urban and industrial wastewater remains untreated 
and  unregulated,4  resulting  in  waterways  that  are  hazardous  to  people’s  health.  Urban 
pressures, combined with environmental degradation, are also increasingly causing conflicts 
over water. The 2004 Water Law includes provisions for a process of IWRM and detailed 
guidelines have been developed; however, actions taken to date to operationalize IWRM have 
been insufficient. In addition, technical and administrative capacities continue to be poorly 
managed because of the failure to decentralize functions and allocate responsibilities between 
national and local agencies.  
 
7.  In Pakistan, more than two thirds of surface water resources have been fully developed. 
Groundwater development has little room for expansion and poor management of groundwater 
resources  has  led  to  an  overdraft  situation  in  many  areas,  with  salinity  and  waterlogging 
adversely  affecting  agricultural  production.  At  current  consumption  rates,  the  burgeoning 
population and the accompanying sharp rise in urban demand will outstrip available supply in 
the next three decades. The resource base of surface water and groundwater is also becoming 
increasingly degraded, rendering it unfit for further exploitation in many areas. In addition, the 
supply of surface water is also vulnerable because of the high variability of flows in the Indus 
River. Pakistan is at a crossroads in the management and development of its water resources 
and will face a crisis if it does not take concrete actions to address current problems. The 
federal and provincial governments share the management of water resources, while provincial 
or local authorities are responsible for most delivery of water services. The IWRM framework is 
weak at all levels, as is capacity and support for improved IWRM is needed, especially at the 
provincial level. 
 
8.  Viet Nam is pursuing the preparation of action plans for IWRM through its national water 
resources  strategy  and  a  wide  range  of  activities  to  address  specific  aspects  of  water 
management. Despite the overall strategy and plan for IWRM, a number of issues require 
immediate attention to improve water management at the local level, for example, management 
of the quality of surface water, subsurface water, and groundwater.  
 
9.  Even  though  all  four  participating  countries  have  promulgated  decrees  covering 
wastewater  discharges  in  an  attempt  to  manage  surface  water,  issues  relating  to  existing 
policies,  processes,  and  technical  matters  still  need  to be  resolved  to  make water  quality 
management workable and to introduce regulatory frameworks at the provincial and local levels. 
In particular, robust and effective measures to help rural communities improve water quality or 
mitigate  the  effects  of  poor  quality  water  are  needed.  In  relation  to  the  management  of 
subsurface water and groundwater, major concerns have been raised by national and local 
water agencies in relation to the rapid deterioration of groundwater resources: both water quality 
and quantity issues are threatening supplies of water to many communities and industries, with 
evidence suggesting that current levels of extraction are unsustainable in many areas.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA will help the governments develop and implement IWRM strategies so that they 
can  achieve  their  World  Summit  for  Sustainable  Development  commitments.  The  TA  will 
strengthen the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework for improved IWRM planning and 
implementation at the national and local levels. The impacts are expected to include clearer 
definition and delineation of functions among national and local agencies and strengthened 
capacities of water management and regulatory agencies. In addition, an adequate and reliable 
database  for  each  country  will  be  established  to  help  with  the  coordination  of  plans  and 
implementation  of  programs  across  sectors  with  respect  to  water  supply  and  demand 
management. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA comprises four major project activities. Their methodologies and key activities 
are described below and specific details for each country are shown in Appendix 2.  
 
12.  Resource  Assessment  and  Indicator  Development.  Existing  patterns  of  water 
management and consumption will be identified. Seasonal variations in both quality and quantity 
of  surface,  subsurface,  and  groundwater  resources  will  be  examined  and  evaluated.  The 
component will identify gaps in past and current IWRM programs and use the lessons learned 
as a guide for undertaking future initiatives. In Indonesia, river basin organizations will be 
classified in accordance with water management needs, for which performance indicators will 
be developed. The activities in Pakistan will include (i) collecting data by means of water sample 
collections  from  major  and/or  critical  water  sources  and  their  analysis;  (ii)  establishing  a 
database; (iii) developing criteria for evaluating the condition of water resources; (iv) developing 
guidance  notes  and  manuals  on  water  resource  assessment  and  the  use  of  monitoring 
indicators; and (v) conducting workshops and training for water management personnel in 
national,  provincial,  and  local  agencies  on  water  resource  assessment  and  the  use  of 
monitoring indicators. In Viet Nam, the TA will identify groundwater sources in the Red River 
delta area and make an initial assessment of water availability from each source as a basis for 
future aquifer management. 
 
13.  Impact Evaluation and Identification of Mitigation Measures. With the resources 
assessed and the indicators established, the TA will evaluate the impacts on human health, 
resource  sustainability,  and  ecosystem  integrity  and  estimate  the  economic  costs  of  such 
impacts. Activities will include (i) conducting extensive research on the possible impacts of 
unsustainable  water  consumption  practices  on  human  health  and  the  environment,  (ii) 
estimating the economic costs of the adverse impacts of such unsustainable practices, and (iii) 
undertaking consultations and training workshops on the identification of mitigation measures 
and the development of action plans. In Bangladesh, activities will include a review of past and 
current  water  management  programs  in  relation  to  promoting  poverty  reduction  and  the 
development of water-poverty indicators. In addition, the TA will help Indonesia and Viet Nam 
design and set up water regulatory and reporting systems to support regulatory councils at the 
national  and  local  levels  in  devising  appropriate  discharge  permits  and  fees  as  mitigation 
measures. 
 
14.  Capacity Building for IWRM Formulation and Implementation at National and Local 
Levels. To assure the effectiveness and implementation of IWRM systems in the four countries,

4   
a thorough review of such systems will be conducted and gaps relating to policy, regulatory, and 
institutional capacities to support implementation at the national and local levels will be identified. 
Recommendations for how to address these gaps will be provided. Activities will include (i) 
assessing current IWRM systems; (ii) consulting with provincial and/or local water management 
agencies to identify implementation gaps; (iii) preparing comprehensive recommendations on 
how to address these gaps; and (iv) holding consultations with and workshops for national, 
provincial, and local water management personnel to promote consensus on the adoption of 
appropriate recommendations. In Bangladesh, national and local capacities will be enhanced to 
motivate political commitment to formulate and implement an IWRM and efficiency plan.5 In 
Indonesia, the roles of water councils will be reviewed and strengthened to link with effective 
IWRM implementation. In Pakistan, the TA will improve IWRM planning and implementation in 
the province of Punjab. In Viet Nam, new capacities will be introduced and existing capacities 
will be updated so that the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and provincial staff 
will be able to implement IWRM processes.  
 
15.  Consultation and Dissemination of Lessons Learned.  A consultative approach will 
be taken in all four countries. Consultations with stakeholders will be conducted throughout TA 
implementation to promote greater understanding of the TA, stimulate public participation, and 
forge  partnerships  among  various  sectors.  The  outputs  and  outcomes  of  the  TA  will  be 
presented  at  public  seminars  and  workshops.  A  network  will  also  be  developed  for  the 
exchange  of  information  and  experiences  among  the  countries,  and  study  visits  will  be 
conducted if necessary. To enhance the replicability of the activities in the four countries in other 
developing  member  countries,  lessons  learned  will  be  documented  and  conferences  and 
workshops  will  be  conducted  for  the  various  stakeholders,  including  representatives  of 
government agencies and the private sector, at which the lessons learned can be shared, 
commitment  to  action  can  be  solicited,  plans  of  action  regarding  IWRM  development  and 
implementation can be adopted, and ADB’s water sector portfolio can be enhanced. The TA will 
also provide for participation by the four countries in such regional activities as the Network of 
Asian River Basin Organizations and the Global Water Partnership. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total project costs are estimated at $1,145,000 equivalent, of which the Government 
of the Netherlands will provide $1,000,000 on a grant basis to be administered by ADB for 
activities within the scope of the TA. The governments will provide counterpart contributions 
totaling $145,000, mainly in kind in the form of counterpart staff, office space and supplies, 
administrative support, services, and logistics. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan 
are presented in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, which will be carried out over 24 months 
from November 2006 to October 2008. The Energy, Transport, and Water Division of the 
Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall 
coordination of the TA activities. The Water Committee and sector divisions in Central and West 
Asia Department, South Asia Department, and Southeast Asia Department will supervise TA 
implementation in the four countries. 
                                                 
5  An IWRM and efficiency plan describes how countries will change their water management in the context of how 
they envisage IWRM and articulates the steps that the countries intend to take to achieve full–scale, sustainable 
water resources development and management. The IWRM and efficiency plan will be reviewed and revised in an 
iterative and consultative way as implementation proceeds.

5
18.  For Bangladesh, the Water Resources Planning Organization of the Ministry of Water 
Resources  will  be  the  implementing  agency  responsible  for  overall  TA  management  and 
coordination. The TA will support a policy advisory group consisting of renowned local water 
sector specialists that will guide the TA and other relevant sector activities. For Indonesia, the 
Directorate General of Water Resources and the Agency for Research and Development, both 
part of the Ministry of Public Works, will be the implementing agencies. For Pakistan, the 
Ministry of Water Resources will be the implementing agency, together with the Provincial 
Planning Commission of Punjab, and will work closely with the Punjab Irrigation and Power 
Department, which is generally responsible for IWRM at the provincial level. For Viet Nam, the 
Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, along with the provincial people’s committees 
in the two target provinces, will be the implementing agency and will coordinate inputs from the 
ministries of Agriculture and Development, Health, Planning and Investment, and others. The 
implementing agencies in each country will organize interministerial meetings to guide the TA 
process. Individual activities will be implemented by the designated line agencies by mobilizing 
existing  working  groups  or  task  forces.  Participation  in  the  organization  of  seminars  and 
workshops will also be sought from local nongovernment organizations, other experts and 
stakeholders, and external funding agencies to seek their feedback on the TA’s outputs. 
 
19.  ADB will engage a national consultant as TA administrator to work at ADB headquarters 
for  approximately  10  months  on  an  intermittent  basis  to  monitor  and  coordinate  TA 
implementation in the four countries. ADB will also contract for a total of 108 person-months of 
consulting  services  (90  person-months  national  and  18  person-months  international)  to 
implement the TA components in the four countries. The international and national consultants 
will be specialists in water resources assessment, IWRM, management information systems, 
data management, monitoring system, environmental and natural resources economics, and 
training. All consultants (both individuals and firms) will be engaged by ADB, in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. For the selection of consulting firms, the quality- 
and cost-based selection method will be used and firms will be required to submit biodata 
technical proposals. However, where appropriate, simplified technical proposals will be required.  
The consultants will work closely with the TA administrator. The outline terms of reference for 
the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
20.  The team of consultants in each country will submit (i) an inception report at the end of 
the 1st month following its mobilization; (ii) brief monthly progress reports; (iii) an interim report 
at the end of the 6th month; (iv) a draft final report at the end of the 11th month; and (v) a final 
report within 3 weeks of the final tripartite meeting between ADB, the implementing agencies, 
and the consultants that incorporates comments by ADB and the implementing agencies. The 
implementing  agencies  will  submit  hard  and  electronic  copies  of  the  final  report  to  ADB. 
Meetings between ADB and the implementing agencies will be held following submission of the 
inception, interim, and draft final reports. The TA’s outputs will be posted on ADB’s web site. 
 
21.  Any procurement of equipment, such as that related to water sampling and analysis and 
data processing, will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Government of the Netherlands for Process Development for Preparing and 
Implementing Integrated Water Resources Management Plans, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES 
 
A.  Bangladesh 
 
1.  The goal of the technical assistance (TA) is to improve water resources management 
and service delivery to move toward the goals of the national water policy (NWP) and the 
national  watershed  management  plan  (NWMP),  that  is,  to  optimize  benefits  in  terms  of 
livelihoods, production, and the environment. The expected outcome is improvements in the 
enabling  environment,  the  performance  of  the  relevant  institutions,  and  the  planning  and 
programming of investment achieved through participatory implementation of specific actions for 
integrated water resources management (IWRM) and better service delivery in line with the 
Government’s commitments at the World Summit for Sustainable Development (WSSD). The 
TA  will  also  raise  stakeholder  awareness,  Government  commitments,  and  momentum  for 
accelerated reforms. To institutionalize the reform process, the TA will use the Government’s 
existing institutional setup and will provide supplementary services and inputs to support the 
activities of the designated organizations. Its activities will be coordinated and harmonized with 
programs by other external financing agencies, in particular, the twinning missions with the 
Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) and Water Resources Planning Organization 
(WARPO) fielded by the Government of the Netherlands. A consultative approach will be taken 
to enhance stakeholder awareness while generating stronger ownership.  
 
2.  The specific TA outputs and activities include the following:  
 
(i)  IWRM implementation plan. An implementation plan will be prepared for IWRM 
during the TA period. For this purpose, the TA will undertake a participatory fact-
finding exercise to (a) review the country’s water sector reforms in light of the 
IWRM  and  efficiency  plan  agendas  of  the  WSSD,  and  (b)  identify  specific 
opportunities and the scope of actions for furthering the agendas during the TA 
implementation period. The plan will be finalized through intensive stakeholder 
consultations and will encompass policy and legal frameworks, institutions for 
IWRM and water service delivery, and priority programs and actions as specified 
under the national water policy and the NWMP.  
 
(ii)  IWRM operationalization and improved service delivery. On the basis of the 
IWRM implementation plan, the TA will support specific actions identified, which 
would include (a) reviewing implementation of the NWP and identifying specific 
actions for its improvement, (b) establishing monitorable water-poverty indicators 
integrating NWMP and the Government's national poverty reduction strategy, (c) 
operationalizing the NWMP annual review process by means of an action plan to 
accelerate its implementation, (d) reviewing the performance of the BWDB and 
devising an action plan for enhanced effectiveness, (e) advancing preparation of 
the draft national water act, (f) finalizing and undertaking initial implementation of 
the organizational development plan of the WARPO, and (g) preparing outputs 
for any other relevant agendas. On the basis of these activities, the TA will also 
support the preparation of biannual reports for the National Water Council to 
report on the TA’s work plan and outputs and an IWRM road map laying out 
short- to medium-term policy and institutional actions and priority investments. 
 
(iii)  Stakeholder  consultation  and  information  dissemination.  National 
stakeholder workshops will be held at TA inception and midway through the TA 
completion stage to seek stakeholders’ feedback on the TA work plan and draft

outputs. Lessons learned will be documented and workshops will be conducted 
with the various stakeholders and representatives of government agencies and 
the private sector to share those lessons. 
 
B.  Indonesia 
 
3.  The  2004  Water  Law  clearly  states  that  IWRM  should  be  carried  out,  key  IWRM 
stakeholders  should  be  identified,  and  a  framework  for  regulation  should  be  defined.  A 
comprehensive IWRM planning and management process already exists, including detailed 
guidelines. Since decentralization in 1999, the operationalization of IWRM has been insufficient 
and concerns have arisen that capacity for effective countrywide implementation of IWRM is 
insufficient. Any analysis of the characteristics of Indonesia’s 80 river basins and the status of 
IWRM implementation therein would show a wide diversity of available natural resources, water 
resource utilization, and river basin organization (RBO) and stakeholder activities.  
 
4.  The benchmarking of RBOs’ performance was a priority activity in the 2004–2005 work 
program of the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations (NARBO). On 3 September 2005, 
the NARBO Performance Benchmarking System was launched at the Second Southeast Asia 
Water Forum in Bali, Indonesia. Four of the 11 pilot RBOs are in Indonesia, demonstrating 
Indonesia’s strong commitment to the NARBO initiative. However, the pilot RBOs are the most 
developed institutions on largely-developed river basins and do not represent the diversity of the 
country’s RBOs. 
 
5.   The TA will work closely with and build on the NARBO initiative and other ongoing IWRM 
activities in Indonesia by (i) reviewing current IWRM practices throughout the archipelago; (ii) 
assessing needs-based, appropriate levels of IWRM based on simple basin characteristics; (iii) 
designing  appropriate  benchmarking  systems;  and  (iv)  benchmarking  river  basins  using 
secondary data sources augmented by and verified with local governments and river basin 
studies.  Links  will  be  established  between  IWRM  capacity-building  needs  and  IWRM 
performance.  Workshops and intensive stakeholder dialogue will be undertaken. 
  
6.  The long-term impact of the TA will be improved and sustainable IWRM. The outcome 
will  determine  the  nature  and  extent  of  any  IWRM  capacity  gap  and  develop  a  targeted 
strengthening approach based on the needs of key stakeholders.  
 
7.  The specific TA outputs and the activities include the following:  
 
(i)  Resource assessment and indicator development. RBOs will be classified in 
terms of (a) national characteristics (demographics, socioeconomic status, and 
governance structure); (b) basin characteristics (size, resources endowments, 
land use, demographics, and infrastructure); and (c) RBO characteristics (age, 
funding, objectives, and membership). Activities will include (a) collecting primary 
and secondary data; (b) setting up a database and performance indicators; (c) 
developing  criteria  for  characterizing  river  basins’  IWRM  status  and  water 
management  needs;  (d)  developing  guidance  notes  and  manuals  on  IWRM 
benchmarking; and (e) facilitating workshops and training for national, provincial, 
and local IWRM stakeholders. 
 
(ii)  Impact  evaluation  and  identification  of  mitigation  measures.  Having 
assessed  water  resources  management  needs  and  established  performance 
indicators,  systems  will  be  designed  and  institutions  identified  for  routine

Appendix 2  11 
management of performance benchmarking. Reporting formats will be designed 
for simple time series reporting within a river basin and across RBOs with similar 
characteristics. These systems will provide summary information for regulatory 
councils at the basin, provincial, and national levels.  
 
(iii)  Capacity building for IWRM formulation and implementation at the national 
and  local  levels. The institutional capacities of government organizations to 
support the implementation of IWRM benchmarking at the national and local 
levels  will  be  identified.  The  roles  of  water  councils,  nongovernment 
organizations,  universities,  and  learned  bodies  will  also  be  reviewed  during 
multistakeholder  workshops.  Benchmarking  indicators  to  monitor  capacity  for 
IWRM  will  include  stakeholder  involvement,  internal  RBO  management,  and 
service provision performance and will be linked to IWRM outcomes. 
 
(iv)  Consultation and dissemination of lessons learned.  TA implementation will 
be carried out following an inclusive, consultative approach involving government 
agencies,  donors,  community,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  community 
stakeholders.  Consultations  with  stakeholders  will  be  conducted  to  promote 
greater  understanding  of  the  TA,  stimulate  public  participation,  and  forge 
partnerships across sector agencies. Lessons learned will be documented and 
multistakeholder workshops will be conducted. 
 
C.  Pakistan 
 
8.  The TA will improve IWRM planning and implementation at the provincial level in Punjab. 
Specifically, the TA will support (i) capacity building for IWRM in water resources management 
agencies, (ii) planning capability for IWRM in key water resources agencies, (iii) strengthening 
of IWRM and reform of water sector institutions and policies, (iv) technical and institutional 
analyses to help develop and implement action plans for IWRM, and (v) consensus-building 
activities in relation to IWRM agendas. 
 
9.  Together, the components should result in the implementation of activities that advance 
the IWRM agenda of the Government of Pakistan and the provincial government of Punjab. 
Deliverables will include (i) planning frameworks, (ii) action plans, (iii) technical and institutional 
analyses and other reports, (iv) a synthesis of the public consultation process that will feed into 
refinement of the planning frameworks and action plans, and (v) a summary report on the 
process and the outcomes that presents lessons and helps institutionalize the action planning 
process. 
 
10.  Specific TA activities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Capacity building for IWRM review and enhancement at the federal and 
provincial levels. The primary focus of the TA is to work with the provincial 
government of Punjab to develop and implement an IWRM action plan by means 
of dialogue with relevant government agencies and other stakeholders. Activities 
will include (a) reviewing and evaluating ongoing and planned activities in the 
water sector, (b) recommending actions and agendas to promote efficiency and 
effectiveness in undertaking the activities consistent with IWRM, (c) coordinating 
the Asian Development Bank’s water sector initiatives in Punjab, (d) developing 
IWRM  planning  frameworks  for  the  provincial  government  of  Punjab,  (e) 
undertaking  technical  and  institutional  analyses  to  support  development  and

12  Appendix 2 
implementation of the IWRM action plan, (f) formulating action plans for the 
provincial government so that it can effectively implement existing and planned 
activities in the water sector, (g) identifying new activities and strategies and 
developing policy reforms to improve IWRM, and (h) formulating an improved 
IWRM framework. 
 
(ii)  Consultation  and  dissemination  of  lessons  learned.  Provincial-level 
stakeholder workshops will be held to solicit feedback on the proposed water 
sector  reforms  and  action  plans.  Lessons  learned  will  be  documented  and 
conferences and workshops will be conducted with the various stakeholders and 
representatives  of  government  agencies  and  the  private  sector  to  share  the 
lessons learned. 
 
D.  Viet Nam 
 
11.  The proposed TA will provide support for developing and implementing the national 
water resources strategy in two critical areas of IWRM, namely, groundwater management and 
wastewater management. The proposed support will institutionalize IWRM in practical ways. 
Specifically, the TA will develop procedures, tools, and implementation options for addressing 
surface water and groundwater management problems that will be applicable at the local level, 
ultimately  with  the  active  engagement  of  local  communities.  By  establishing  the  base 
information required to manage these resources, the TA will enable the Ministry of Natural 
Resources and Environment (MoNRE) to assess and define actions to further enhance the 
policy,  regulatory,  and  institutional  framework  needed  to  support  local-level  approaches  to 
IWRM that focus on poverty reduction. 
 
12.  Specific activities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Resource assessment and indicator. Viet Nam will face daunting challenges 
related to water resources in the future and must establish a firm foundation for 
effective management of these resources. This TA will help MoNRE (a) identify 
and apply techniques and indicators for assessing the quality and quantity of 
surface,  subground,  and  groundwater  resources  in  selected  locations;  (b) 
evaluate the extent of aquifer and groundwater resources for the major Red River 
basin aquifers, identifying major areas of extraction; (c) establish systems and 
procedures for the use of water quality indicators developed by the Ministry of 
Health in relation to major effluent discharges from selected industries; (d) design 
a monitoring network for water quality (bacteriological and toxin contamination) 
based on the indicators developed for selected industry discharge locations that 
should  include  estimates  of  the  capital  and  recurrent  costs  of  operating  the 
network together with proposals for funding the operations; and (e) facilitate 
workshops and training for national, provincial, and local water management 
personnel on water resource assessment and use of monitoring indicators. 
 
(ii)  Impact evaluation and identification of mitigation measures. Poor quality 
surface water and groundwater have disproportionate impacts on the poor. The 
negative impacts of low-quality water on incomes, health, and the environment 
are increasingly being recognized. The TA will help MoNRE establish working 
arrangements  with  polluting  industries  and  undertake  appropriate  discharge 
management  and  effluent  treatment  to  mitigate  and  reverse  impacts  on  the 
environment, the river system, and the communities in the vicinity of selected

Appendix 2  13 
industries and representative sites in the Red River basin and elsewhere. The TA 
will include (a) reviewing and assessing international approaches to industrial 
wastewater  management,  (b)  holding  consultations  and  workshops  on  the 
identification  of  best-practice  wastewater  management  strategies  and  the 
development of action plans, and (c) establishing conditions for an industrial 
discharge permitting system.  
 
(iii)  Capacity building for IWRM review and improvement at the national and 
local levels. The TA components will introduce new capabilities among MoNRE 
and  provincial  staff  for  implementing  IWRM  processes  or  extend  existing 
capacities. The TA will help MoNRE with (a) assessing current IWRM systems 
and procedures; (b) reviewing policy, regulatory, and institutional capacities to 
support and implement quality management of groundwater and surface water 
resources at the national and local levels; (c) consulting with provincial and/or 
local  water  management  agencies  to  identify  capacity  gaps;  (d)  preparing 
comprehensive recommendations indicating measures to fill these gaps; and (e) 
holding consultations and workshops with national, provincial, and local water 
management personnel to promote consensus on the adoption of appropriate 
recommendations. 
 
13.  The TA is expected to produce the following outputs: (i) guidelines for local IWRM that 
include surface water and groundwater quality management as integral elements of the process; 
(ii) indicators, tools, and guidelines for assessing surface water quality, groundwater quantity, 
and  sustainability;  (iii)  assessment  of  selected  technological  management,  regulatory,  and 
economic mechanisms for addressing specific problems associated with surface water quality 
and groundwater management based on an assessment of existing models of good practice in 
Viet Nam; (iv) appropriate data management linked to a global information system to support 
implementation of the TA’s findings, initially in the Red River basin and ultimately nationwide; (v) 
assessment of national policies on surface water quality and groundwater management linked 
to the national water resources strategy and implementation of the comprehensive poverty 
reduction and growth strategy; and (vi) outline of a strategic framework for priority actions to 
improve surface water quality and groundwater management that includes the actions needed 
to enhance the policy, regulatory, and institutional framework to achieve improvements to local 
IWRM.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Bangladesh 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage a team of individual international and 
national  consultants  for  a  total  of  37  person-months.  The  TA  must  deliver  specific 
recommendations to advance reforms in the four distinct areas in Bangladesh, including overall 
policy framework, IWRM, irrigation service delivery and flood management, and water supply 
and sanitation. Given that the best qualified consultants in these areas may not be readily 
available from a single institution, engaging individual consultants is necessary to ensure the 
highest  expertise  in  the  team,  and  was  also  recommended  by  the  EA.  However,  where 
appropriate and feasible, preference will be given to recruiting consulting firms instead individual 
consultants.  
 
  1.  Water Management Specialist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The water management specialist will work closely with the Ministry of Water Resources 
(MoWR),  the  Water  Resources  Planning  Organization  (WARPO),  the  Bangladesh  Water 
Development Board (BWDB), and the Department of Public Health Engineering to support 
implementation of the technical assistance (TA). Under the guidance of the secretary, MoWR, 
and the ADB task manager, the specialist will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare a general overview report of water sector reforms in Bangladesh in light 
of the integrated water resources management (IWRM), efficiency plan agenda 
and  ADB’s  water  policy,  specifying  (a) performance  gaps;  (b)  institutions  for 
IWRM and service delivery; and (c) priority investments as specified under the 
national watershed management plan (NWMP).  
(ii)  Identify specific opportunities for promoting water sector reforms under the TA, 
and expanding them as appropriate, and propose activities to be pursued. 
(iii)  Prepare a draft report within 1 month of commencing work synthesizing the 
findings and present a draft work plan for the TA. 
(iv)  Provide  periodic  advice  on  the  implementation  of  specific  activities  by  the 
national consultants under the guidance of the policy advisory group. 
(v)  Review activity outputs in the draft final report and provide intensive support to 
prepare  short-  and  medium-term  action  agendas  and  action  plans  that  the 
Government should consider as follow-on actions to the TA. 
 
2.  Water Sector Advisory Group (national, 4 specialists, total of 9 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
3.  A water sector advisory group (WSAG) consisting of reputable local experts will be 
formed to advise MoWR on accelerating the implementation of water sector reforms, with the 
support of the TA, in terms of (i) furthering implementation of the NWMP; (ii) strengthening the 
NWMP and its implementation; (iii) promoting further institutional reforms of sector agencies; 
and (iv) establishing a legal framework. This may encompass both water resource management 
and service delivery functions. 
 
4.  MoWR will select WSAG members in consultation with ADB and they will be engaged by 
ADB. WSAG will consist of advisers on (i) policy and institutional development (2.5 person-
months); (ii) IWRM (2.5 person-months); (iii) river management, including flood control and river 
erosion, drainage, and irrigation (2.5 person-months); and (iv) water supply (1.5 person-months).

16  Appendix 4 
The secretary of MoWR will appoint the chair. The WSAG will (i) advise on the activities of the 
international water management specialist in undertaking comprehensive water sector reform 
assessments and preparing the TA work plan by identifying specific gaps and action agenda; (ii) 
advise  the  team  of  specialists,  who  will  be  engaged  from  a  firm  and/or  nongovernment 
organization (NGO) or research institute, in addressing the specific actions defined under the 
TA  work  plan;  and  (iii)  support  MoWR  in  preparing  water  sector  policy,  institutional,  and 
investment activity reports to be submitted and discussed by the National Water Council (NWC). 
 
3.  Specialists for Designated Agendas (national 4 specialists, total of 26 person-
months, intermittent)  
 
5.  A  team  of  national  water  resources  specialists  will  be  engaged  from  a 
firm/NGO/research institute to help the relevant Government agencies undertake the specific 
activities in close collaboration with the counterpart agency working group, including the task 
force  groups  established  under  the  twinning missions in  the  case of  WARPO  and  BWDB 
activities,  and  with  the  guidance  and  support  of  the  WSAG.  The  team  will  consist  of  the 
following: (i) a water management policy and institutional specialist (4 person-months), (ii) an 
IWRM specialist (9 person-months), (iii) a water management specialist (9 person-months), and 
(iv) a water supply policy and institutional specialist (4 person-months). The team will organize 
intensive consultations with civil society, local experts, WSAG members, and local consultative 
subgroups  on  water  management  at  seminars  and  workshops  in  close  contact  with,  and 
facilitation by, designated staff in the Bangladesh Resident Mission. 
 
6.  The team’s activities will include the following: 
 
(i)  Review  the  implementation  status  of  the  national  water  policy;  assess  its 
performance gaps; identify and support specific actions for achieving its goals.  
(ii)  Review the framework and content of the NWMP and its linkage with the Poverty 
Reduction Strategic Plan (PRSP) and identify and support actions to strengthen it.  
(iii)  Operationalize the regular review process of NWMP implementation.  
(iv)  Review the progress of reforms for operationalizing IWRM, including integrated 
planning and programming, surface water and groundwater quantity and quality 
management, knowledge and database management; and identify and support 
the implementation of specific agendas/actions to strengthen its operation.  
(v)  Support the finalization and implementation of the organizational development 
strategy and plan for WARPO to operationalize functions envisaged under the 
national water policy to further IWRM reforms.    
(vi)  Support  the  implementation  review  of  the  2000  BWDB  Act  and  associated 
institutional reforms covering the agendas being pursued by BWDB. 
(vii)  Support the ongoing policy and program formulation and implementation and 
institutional reforms in the water supply and sanitation sector to operationalize 
the 1998 National Policy for Safe Water Supply and Sanitation, the 2004 Sector 
Development Framework, and the 2004 National Policy for Arsenic Mitigation. 
(viii)  Facilitate the resumption of the preparation of a draft national water act, including 
initiating priority operations for water resources management on a pilot basis. 
(ix)  Undertake any other actions deemed necessary by the Government to further the 
IWRM and efficiency plan implementation process.  
(x)  Synthesize the TA findings into a sector road map that clearly lays out short- and 
medium-term policy, institutional, and investment actions and outputs. 
(xi)  Help MoWR prepare water sector policy, institutional, and investment activity 
reports and periodically submit them to NWC and its executive committee.

engaged for approximately 30 person-months over a 5-month period from a firm/NGO/research

Agency for Research and Development. The team will consist of (i) an institutional management 
specialist, (ii) a group of institutional organization specialists, (iii) an IWRM human resources 
specialist,  (iv)  an  IWRM  benchmarking  specialist,  (v)  an  IWRM  specialist,  (vi)  a 
hydrologist/natural resources information system specialist, and (vii) an IWRM management

stakeholders  by  means  of  seminars  and  workshops  in  close  contact  with  the  Directorate 
General of Water Resources and the Agency for Research and Development. 
 
9.  The team will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Identify IWRM stakeholders, including making visits to 8 provinces, 24 districts, 
and 16 river basin organizations (RBOs). 
(ii)  Review current IWRM practices throughout the archipelago. 
(iii)  Assess needs-based, appropriate levels of IWRM based on basin characteristics. 
(iv)  Classify river basins and their RBOs into two to four categories based on the 
level  of  sophistication of  IWRM  required  for  appropriate  management  of  the

TA. Their tasks shall include the following:

(v)  Review the current investment and asset management program for IWRM and 
irrigation infrastructure; provide recommendations with regard to priority sector 
investments,  an  improved  process  for  identifying  sector  investments,  and 
development of an asset management plan. 
(vi)  Review the current role of water users with regard to participation in water sector 
decision making and management and provide recommendations to improve 
accountability and the role of water users in the management of water resources
